description.narrative:
The Food and Beverage (F<(>&<)>B) industry is a key driver of climate change, with greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from agriculture,deforestation and land use change amounting to a quarter of the world#s total emissions. A succession of powerful public campaigns from Oxfam and our allies, including Oxfam#s BtB campaign,1 have compelled companies in the F<(>&<)>B sector, as well as several major commodity traders, to recently announce new policies that begin to tackle this problem. Nine of the ten largest F<(>&<)>B companies have now adopted deforestation-free, peat-free and exploitation-free palm oil commitments and seven have adopted commitments to achieve zero net deforestation across all high-climate risk commodities.2 Six of the ten companies have committed to establishing science-based emissions reduction goals.3
While progress has been made in securing these deforestation commitments, they represent thefirst step on the journey towards achieving deforestation-free supply chains and reversing the current upward trend of emissions generated from agriculture and land use change. Companies need to start embedding their high-level commitments into sourcing policies and practices and ensure that their suppliers uphold the environmental and social standardsthey have committed to. Further, these policy commitments don#t adequately address the social and human rights challenges associated with deforestation, and have yet to translate into impacts on the ground in countries and communities where these commodities are sourced from.
Moving forward, it will be critical to hold companies accountable to deliver on their commitments while supporting efforts to strengthen their implementation. This calls for a focus on monitoring how companies are engaging their suppliers and putting in place time-bound plans for achieving greater transparency, traceability and transformation in their supply chains; ensuring that rights and livelihoods of local communities are protected and enhanced in the implementation ofdeforestation commitments; and facilitating meaningful community buy-in and participation, as well as alignment with national policies and land use governance in countries where these commodities are sourced.
Oxfam in Indonesia, together with OxfamAmerica and Oxfam Novib, will link global advocacy with country-level advocacy, with a focuson advising and monitoring companies# implementation of policies <(>&<)> commitments to track the on-the-ground impact on communities and the environment. This includes using findings from Community Based Human Rights Impact Assessments (COBHRAs) and company-community meetings which will be implemented by Oxfam in Indonesia to inform engagement
The following two activities will be funded through this project:
o Activity 3.2: Support community based human rights impact assessments (COBHRA)7 in the palm sector in Indonesia # findings from the assessments will be used to monitor the implementation of commitments on the ground, and engage companies on actions to addressgaps. o Activity 3.3: Convene company # community/CSO dialogues in Indonesia

participating-org.narrative:
Novib in 1994 became a member of Oxfam International. A group of twelve independent, like-minded development organizations strivingfor a fairer world.
Oxfam's work with a total of 3,000 partner organizations in 100 countries. They maintain contacts with severalmajor international networks and civil society organizations. The collaboration began with advocacy but also extends to the projectwork and joint campaigning and relief.
One of the members of Oxfam International, Oxfam GB, an independent British organization. Oxfam GB works with volunteers, donors. Oxfam GB has an office in Jakarta.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
